trans-unit.source: Managing Role-Based Access Control with Azure Command-Line Interface
trans-unit.target: Managing Role-Based Access Control with Azure Command-Line Interface

trans-unit.source: Managing role-based access control with Azure Command-Line Interface
trans-unit.target: Managing role-based access control with Azure Command-Line Interface

trans-unit.source: Managing Role-Based Access Control with the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI)
trans-unit.target: Managing Role-Based Access Control with the Azure Command-Line Interface (Azure CLI)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Role-based access control (RBAC) in Azure Portal and Azure Resource Manager API allows you to manage access to your subscription and resources at a fine-grained level.
trans-unit.target: Role-based access control (RBAC) in Azure Portal and Azure Resource Manager API allows you to manage access to your subscription and resources at a fine-grained level.

trans-unit.source: With this feature, you can grant access for Active Directory users, groups, or service principals by assigning some roles to them at a particular scope.
trans-unit.target: With this feature, you can grant access for Active Directory users, groups, or service principals by assigning some roles to them at a particular scope.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to use Azure CLI to manage role based access control.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to use Azure CLI to manage role based access control.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through the process of creating and checking role assignments.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through the process of creating and checking role assignments.

trans-unit.source: **Estimated time to complete:** 15 minutes
trans-unit.target: **Estimated time to complete:** 15 minutes

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Before you can use Azure CLI to manage RBAC, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you can use Azure CLI to manage RBAC, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI version 0.8.8 or later.
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI version 0.8.8 or later.

trans-unit.source: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see [Install and Configure the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli.md).
trans-unit.target: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see [Install and Configure the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli.md).

trans-unit.source: Please also read the following tutorials to get familiar with set up and using Azure Resource Manager in Azure CLI: [Using the Azure CLI with the Resource Manager](../xplat-cli-azure-resource-manager.md)
trans-unit.target: Please also read the following tutorials to get familiar with set up and using Azure Resource Manager in Azure CLI: [Using the Azure CLI with the Resource Manager](../xplat-cli-azure-resource-manager.md)

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial

trans-unit.target: Connect to your subscriptions

trans-unit.target: Check existing role assignments

trans-unit.target: Create a role assignment

trans-unit.source: Connect to your subscriptions
trans-unit.target: Connect to your subscriptions

trans-unit.source: Since RBAC only works with Azure Resource Manager, the first thing to do is to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: Since RBAC only works with Azure Resource Manager, the first thing to do is to switch to Azure Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: For more information, please refer to [Using the Azure CLI with the Resource Manager](../xplat-cli-azure-resource-manager.md)
trans-unit.target: For more information, please refer to [Using the Azure CLI with the Resource Manager](../xplat-cli-azure-resource-manager.md)

trans-unit.source: To connect to your Azure subscriptions, type:
trans-unit.target: To connect to your Azure subscriptions, type:

trans-unit.source: In the command line prompt, enter you Azure account password (only use an organizational account).
trans-unit.target: In the command line prompt, enter you Azure account password (only use an organizational account).

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI will get all the subscriptions you have with this account and configure itself to use the first one as default.
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI will get all the subscriptions you have with this account and configure itself to use the first one as default.

trans-unit.source: Notice that with role based access control, you will only be able to get the subscriptions where you have some permissions by either being its co-admin or having some role assignment.
trans-unit.target: Notice that with role based access control, you will only be able to get the subscriptions where you have some permissions by either being its co-admin or having some role assignment.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to switch to another one, type:
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple subscriptions and want to switch to another one, type:

trans-unit.source: For more information, please refer to [Install and Configure the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, please refer to [Install and Configure the Azure CLI](../xplat-cli.md).

trans-unit.source: Check existing role assignments
trans-unit.target: Check existing role assignments

trans-unit.source: Now let's check what role assignments exist in the subscription already.
trans-unit.target: Now let's check what role assignments exist in the subscription already.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: This will return all the role assignments in the subscription.
trans-unit.target: This will return all the role assignments in the subscription.

trans-unit.source: Two things to notice:
trans-unit.target: Two things to notice:

trans-unit.source: You'll need to have read access at the subscription level.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to have read access at the subscription level.

trans-unit.source: If the subscription has a lot of role assignments, it may take a while to get all of them.
trans-unit.target: If the subscription has a lot of role assignments, it may take a while to get all of them.

trans-unit.source: You can also check existing role assignments for a particular role definition, at a particular scope for a particular user.
trans-unit.target: You can also check existing role assignments for a particular role definition, at a particular scope for a particular user.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: This will return all the role assignments for a particular user in your Azure AD directory, who has a role assignment of "Owner" for resource group "group1".
trans-unit.target: This will return all the role assignments for a particular user in your Azure AD directory, who has a role assignment of "Owner" for resource group "group1".

trans-unit.source: The role assignment can come from two places:
trans-unit.target: The role assignment can come from two places:

trans-unit.source: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the resource group.
trans-unit.target: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the resource group.

trans-unit.source: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the parent of the resource group (the subscription in this case) because if you have any permission at a certain parent resource, you'll have the same permissions to all its children resources.
trans-unit.target: A role assignment of "Owner" to the user for the parent of the resource group (the subscription in this case) because if you have any permission at a certain parent resource, you'll have the same permissions to all its children resources.

trans-unit.source: All the parameters of this cmdlet are optional.
trans-unit.target: All the parameters of this cmdlet are optional.

trans-unit.source: You can combine them to check role assignments with different filters.
trans-unit.target: You can combine them to check role assignments with different filters.

trans-unit.source: Create a role assignment
trans-unit.target: Create a role assignment

trans-unit.source: To create a role assignment, you need to think about:
trans-unit.target: To create a role assignment, you need to think about:

trans-unit.source: Who you want to assign the role to: you can use the following Azure Active Directory cmdlets to see what users, groups and service principals you have in your directory.
trans-unit.target: Who you want to assign the role to: you can use the following Azure Active Directory cmdlets to see what users, groups and service principals you have in your directory.

trans-unit.source: What role you want to assign: you can use the following cmdlet to see the supported role definitions.
trans-unit.target: What role you want to assign: you can use the following cmdlet to see the supported role definitions.

trans-unit.source: What scope you want to assign: you have three levels for scopes:
trans-unit.target: What scope you want to assign: you have three levels for scopes:

trans-unit.source: The current subscription
trans-unit.target: The current subscription

trans-unit.source: A resource group.
trans-unit.target: A resource group.

trans-unit.source: To get a list of resource groups, type `azure group list`
trans-unit.target: To get a list of resource groups, type `azure group list`

trans-unit.source: A resource.
trans-unit.target: A resource.

trans-unit.source: To get a list of resources, type `azure resource list`
trans-unit.target: To get a list of resources, type `azure resource list`

trans-unit.source: Then use `azure role assignment create` to create a role assignment.
trans-unit.target: Then use `azure role assignment create` to create a role assignment.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment at the current subscription level for a user as a reader:
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment at the current subscription level for a user as a reader:

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment at a resource group level:
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment at a resource group level:

trans-unit.source: This will create a role assignment at a resource level:
trans-unit.target: This will create a role assignment at a resource level:

trans-unit.source: Verify permissions
trans-unit.target: Verify permissions

trans-unit.source: After you check that your account has some role assignments, you can actually see the permissions these role assignments grant you by running:
trans-unit.target: After you check that your account has some role assignments, you can actually see the permissions these role assignments grant you by running:

trans-unit.source: These two cmdlets will only return the resource groups or resources where you have read permission.
trans-unit.target: These two cmdlets will only return the resource groups or resources where you have read permission.

trans-unit.source: And it will show you the permissions you have as well.
trans-unit.target: And it will show you the permissions you have as well.

trans-unit.source: Then when you try to run other cmdlets like `azure group create`, you will get an access denied error if you don't have the permission.
trans-unit.target: Then when you try to run other cmdlets like `azure group create`, you will get an access denied error if you don't have the permission.
